intro: Turanecio lazicus, commonly known as the Central Asian bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the steppes of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open grasslands and rocky areas. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it is more commonly encountered in its natural habitat.
